For other systems, it can mean something else. Thoughts?

content.raw: I think that components usually need to have more explicit semantics, that's why we shouldn't have a `Vector3` component, and instead have `LinearVelocity`, `AngularVelocity`, `Scale`, etc. What would it mean to ask for all entities that have a `NameSet`? And what if a level needs to carry another property which is also a set of strings? Another way to think of it is, when an entity's `NameSet` is displayed on a GUI, what label does it have?

content.raw: Is there a way to differentiate entities which are being erased because they're outside the level but they should show up later, and entities which are erased forever?
content.html: Is there a way to differentiate entities which are being erased because they're outside the level but they should show up later, and entities which are erased forever?

content.raw: For reference, game engines usually “move” entities into a temporary staging area when they might get reused later, rather than “erasing” them. It would probably be a good idea to explicitly take that approach, and have completely distinct methods for hiding vs erasing?
content.html: For reference, game engines usually “move” entities into a temporary staging area when they might get reused later, rather than “erasing” them. It would probably be a good idea to explicitly take that approach, and have completely distinct methods for hiding vs erasing?

content.raw:
My initial approach was to never erase entities. Instead I had a bool `RenderState` component that was set by the level manager. However, I noticed that just having a large number of entities in the `EntityComponentManager` caused the RTF to go down significantly. I can look into moving the entities somewhere else so they don't participate in calls to `Each*`. 
So then we would have three states of an entity: "active", "inactive" and "erased". If we go ahead with this idea:

* ** ign-gui/ign-rendering**: When entities are "inactive", should they be destroyed or hidden (detached from the parent visual) in ign-gui/Scene3D? If they are only hidden, wouldn't we have a memory problem as the simulation progresses and loads more resources into the rendering engine? 
* **ign-physics**: I guess if the physics engine supports disabling entities, "inactive" would mean disable. Otherwise, we would remove the entity from the physics engine for both "inactive" and "erased". There might still be two scenarios here: 
1. The physics engine supports ref counting, so if an entity is "inactive", we would remove it from the engine but keep a reference  so that the memory isn't cleaned up. 
2. The physics engine does not support ref counting, so for both "inactive" and "erased", we would remove the entity and leave it to the physics engine to clean up memory as it chooses. If the entity becomes "active" again, a new corresponding entity may have to created inside the physics engine. 
Does that sound right?
content.html:
My initial approach was to never erase entities. Instead I had a bool RenderState component that was set by the level manager. However, I noticed that just having a large number of entities in the EntityComponentManager caused the RTF to go down significantly. I can look into moving the entities somewhere else so they don't participate in calls to Each*. So then we would have three states of an entity: "active", "inactive" and "erased". If we go ahead with this idea:

  • ign-gui/ign-rendering: When entities are "inactive", should they be destroyed or hidden (detached from the parent visual) in ign-gui/Scene3D? If they are only hidden, wouldn't we have a memory problem as the simulation progresses and loads more resources into the rendering engine?
  • ign-physics: I guess if the physics engine supports disabling entities, "inactive" would mean disable. Otherwise, we would remove the entity from the physics engine for both "inactive" and "erased". There might still be two scenarios here: 1. The physics engine supports ref counting, so if an entity is "inactive", we would remove it from the engine but keep a reference so that the memory isn't cleaned up. 2. The physics engine does not support ref counting, so for both "inactive" and "erased", we would remove the entity and leave it to the physics engine to clean up memory as it chooses. If the entity becomes "active" again, a new corresponding entity may have to created inside the physics engine. Does that sound right?

content.raw:
> **ign-gui/ign-rendering**: When entities are "inactive", should they be destroyed or hidden 

I don’t have enough experience with Ogre, but I know that for OpenSceneGraph something that’s worked for me is to remove objects from the scene graph without deleting them. That improves rendering performance without completely deleting those graphics resources, so they could easily be added back into the scene graph when they’re needed. The catch is, if you have really really super large/detailed environments, you could run out of RAM if the whole environment is too big to store all at once. This is basically what video games have loading screens for: changing what graphics asset information is currently being held in RAM.

I think the choice between the two will depend a lot on the specific application. Ideally we could have a way to offer both behaviors, but I don’t know exactly what that would look like. For now we should probably choose one to start with and see how it works for our use case.

> **ign-physics**: I guess if the physics engine supports disabling entities, "inactive" would mean disable. Otherwise, we would remove the entity from the physics engine for both "inactive" and "erased".

I completely agree with this. The hard part will be identifying which physics engines offer that behavior \(because that information can’t be inferred from the feature system alone\). This shouldn’t be any trouble once we have the “Behavior System” implemented, but that hasn’t really made it to my TODO list at the moment \(unfortunately\).
content.html:
ign-gui/ign-rendering: When entities are "inactive", should they be destroyed or hidden 

I don’t have enough experience with Ogre, but I know that for OpenSceneGraph something that’s worked for me is to remove objects from the scene graph without deleting them. That improves rendering performance without completely deleting those graphics resources, so they could easily be added back into the scene graph when they’re needed. The catch is, if you have really really super large/detailed environments, you could run out of RAM if the whole environment is too big to store all at once. This is basically what video games have loading screens for: changing what graphics asset information is currently being held in RAM.

I think the choice between the two will depend a lot on the specific application. Ideally we could have a way to offer both behaviors, but I don’t know exactly what that would look like. For now we should probably choose one to start with and see how it works for our use case.

ign-physics: I guess if the physics engine supports disabling entities, "inactive" would mean disable. Otherwise, we would remove the entity from the physics engine for both "inactive" and "erased".

I completely agree with this. The hard part will be identifying which physics engines offer that behavior (because that information can’t be inferred from the feature system alone). This shouldn’t be any trouble once we have the “Behavior System” implemented, but that hasn’t really made it to my TODO list at the moment (unfortunately).

content.raw:
> I don’t have enough experience with Ogre, but I know that for OpenSceneGraph something that’s worked for me is to remove objects from the scene graph without deleting them. 

yep ign-rendering offers a [Node::RemoveChild](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/src/0cf449a6f94868b9c52bebc63cb0d9f7439bb354/include/ignition/rendering/Node.hh#lines-218) to detach a child node. The other option is to use [Scene::DestroyNode](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/src/0cf449a6f94868b9c52bebc63cb0d9f7439bb354/include/ignition/rendering/Scene.hh#lines-210) to delete it forever.
content.html:
I don’t have enough experience with Ogre, but I know that for OpenSceneGraph something that’s worked for me is to remove objects from the scene graph without deleting them. 

yep ign-rendering offers a Node::RemoveChild to detach a child node. The other option is to use Scene::DestroyNode to delete it forever.

content.raw:
I like the idea of the entity graph, but I think right now it is duplicating the responsibility of 2 other features:

* `components::ParentEntity`: if systems had a graph easily available, they could query the graph and we wouldn't need a component to hold that information.
 * The `entities` vector inside `EntityComponentManager`: That vector holds all entities, and now this graph also holds them all (split by levels).

I haven't thought this through, but maybe we could avoid this duplication by converting the `EntityComponentManager::entities` into a graph, making it available for querying to all systems and to the `LevelManager`. This would be helpful to other systems too, for example the `SceneBroadcaster` wouldn't need to maintain its own graph anymore.

Thoughts? Performance concerns?
content.html:
I like the idea of the entity graph, but I think right now it is duplicating the responsibility of 2 other features:

  • components::ParentEntity: if systems had a graph easily available, they could query the graph and we wouldn't need a component to hold that information.
  • The entities vector inside EntityComponentManager: That vector holds all entities, and now this graph also holds them all (split by levels).

I haven't thought this through, but maybe we could avoid this duplication by converting the EntityComponentManager::entities into a graph, making it available for querying to all systems and to the LevelManager. This would be helpful to other systems too, for example the SceneBroadcaster wouldn't need to maintain its own graph anymore.

Thoughts? Performance concerns?

content.raw:
I like this idea.  It seems like something that people would want to be able to query from various locations \(as you noted\).  It does seem like we could reduce this duplication.

I can’t think of any immediate performance concerns.  Where/when would be the best time to mutate this graph though?  Would each individual system be able to mutate or just query?
content.html:
I like this idea. It seems like something that people would want to be able to query from various locations (as you noted). It does seem like we could reduce this duplication.

I can’t think of any immediate performance concerns. Where/when would be the best time to mutate this graph though? Would each individual system be able to mutate or just query?

content.raw:
I would imagine the graph being read-only by external classes, and it will be updated by the ECM every time an entity is added or removed. This means we'll need to add the option of passing a parent entity when an entity is created, and this may touch a lot of the API. In the future, we can also add functions to reparent entities, which would also touch the graph.

I can take a stab at a quick POC for this so we all can have a better feel of what it would look like. It will also be good to use the profiler to see how performance will be affected, I'm not sure we've done a lot of profiling of the graph class in ign-math.
content.html:
I would imagine the graph being read-only by external classes, and it will be updated by the ECM every time an entity is added or removed. This means we'll need to add the option of passing a parent entity when an entity is created, and this may touch a lot of the API. In the future, we can also add functions to reparent entities, which would also touch the graph.

I can take a stab at a quick POC for this so we all can have a better feel of what it would look like. It will also be good to use the profiler to see how performance will be affected, I'm not sure we've done a lot of profiling of the graph class in ign-math.

content.raw:
I also like the idea. Since the `Each*` calls use views, I don't think we'd have a performance issue. I don't think systems should be allowed to mutate the graph directly. Instead, they can add/remove entities as normal and the graph is mutated as necessary by the `EntityComponentManager`. This probably means we'll need a staging scheme for adding/removing entities to the graph.

Systems like `SceneBroadcaster` currently attach their own data to the vertices of the graph. They will have to store the data somewhere else and use a map from vertex to data.
content.html:
I also like the idea. Since the Each* calls use views, I don't think we'd have a performance issue. I don't think systems should be allowed to mutate the graph directly. Instead, they can add/remove entities as normal and the graph is mutated as necessary by the EntityComponentManager. This probably means we'll need a staging scheme for adding/removing entities to the graph.

Systems like SceneBroadcaster currently attach their own data to the vertices of the graph. They will have to store the data somewhere else and use a map from vertex to data.

content.raw: Good point about the extra data being stored in the graph, I hadn't noticed that.
content.html: Good point about the extra data being stored in the graph, I hadn't noticed that.

Argh, if we remove components::ParentEntity in favor of a graph, we can't do things like this anymore:

Entity Model::LinkByName(const EntityComponentManager &_ecm,
    const std::string &_name)
{
  return _ecm.EntityByComponents(
      components::ParentEntity(this->dataPtr->id),
      components::Name(_name),
      components::Link());
}

Unless we keep both the graph and the component... and have 2 sources of truth that need to be kept in sync

Or.... we can have new fancy functions that take advantage of the graph, like ChildByComponents, but that would touch the views, which is way more refactoring than I was hoping to do here...

content.raw: I'll keep burying myself in this hole a bit longer
content.html: I'll keep burying myself in this hole a bit longer

My next steps are to remove the graph from `LevelManager` and see if I can reuse the graph on `SceneBroadcaster`. Then I'll make a PR against this branch so ppl can take a look.

content.raw: I always thought of the SDF as an initialization object that is thrown away after used. Keeping it around means that it will end up outdated with respect to the current simulation state. Do we really want other classes to keep pointers to child nodes that will end up out of sync?
content.html: I always thought of the SDF as an initialization object that is thrown away after used. Keeping it around means that it will end up outdated with respect to the current simulation state. Do we really want other classes to keep pointers to child nodes that will end up out of sync?

content.raw: The reasoning behind this is that with the level manager, the whole world is not loaded into the ECM at initialization. Instead only the models in the active levels are loaded at a time. To do that, we need to keep the `sdf::World` node in memory and accessible to the `LevelManager`. I chose to keep the `sdf::World` node in `SimulationRunner`, but to keep the world node, we need to keep the `sdf::Root` object as well.
content.html: The reasoning behind this is that with the level manager, the whole world is not loaded into the ECM at initialization. Instead only the models in the active levels are loaded at a time. To do that, we need to keep the sdf::World node in memory and accessible to the LevelManager. I chose to keep the sdf::World node in SimulationRunner, but to keep the world node, we need to keep the sdf::Root object as well.

content.raw: This should be a shared pointer since LevelManager is maintaining ownership of SimulationRunner.
content.html: This should be a shared pointer since LevelManager is maintaining ownership of SimulationRunner.

content.raw: So `SimulationRunner` also contains a pointer to `LevelManager`. In fact, `SimulationRunner` has ownership of `LevelManager` and this pointer here is a non-owning pointer.
content.html: So SimulationRunner also contains a pointer to LevelManager. In fact, SimulationRunner has ownership of LevelManager and this pointer here is a non-owning pointer.

content.raw:
My issue is that this class depends on the pointer being valid throughout the life of this class. The pointer is assumed to be valid, whereas a shared_ptr guarantees that the pointer will be valid.

How do you feel about ensuring that only the simulation runner can create a level manager, and leave this as a raw pointer? You could make the constructor a private friend to the simulation runner. Or make the level manager a private internal class of the simulation runner.

I'm also okay if you want to punt on this, especially since we haven't come up with a good method for dependency injection. If you want to punt, then I can create an issue for this.
content.html:
My issue is that this class depends on the pointer being valid throughout the life of this class. The pointer is assumed to be valid, whereas a shared_ptr guarantees that the pointer will be valid.

How do you feel about ensuring that only the simulation runner can create a level manager, and leave this as a raw pointer? You could make the constructor a private friend to the simulation runner. Or make the level manager a private internal class of the simulation runner.

I'm also okay if you want to punt on this, especially since we haven't come up with a good method for dependency injection. If you want to punt, then I can create an issue for this.

content.raw: +1 to revisiting this with more time later. I think we eventually need to make the architecture clearer by defining precise roles for `Server`, `SimulationRunner`, `LevelManager` and `EntityComponentManager` and defining the relationships between them.
content.html: +1 to revisiting this with more time later. I think we eventually need to make the architecture clearer by defining precise roles for Server, SimulationRunner, LevelManager and EntityComponentManager and defining the relationships between them.

content.raw: I had originally implemented the functionality of the `LevelManager` inside `SimulationRunner`. I decided to move it into its own class so that we can create other types of level managers down the road.  It's also fairly isolated from the rest of the `SimulationRunner`'s functionality so it made sense to do it. But it's definitely meant to be owned by an instance of a `SimulationRunner` and should not outlive that instance. I like the idea of making it a private internal class, but I'd vote for punting if we're going to change the roles of the classes as @chapulina [mentioned](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/111/a-1-levels/activity#comment-90218041).
content.html: I had originally implemented the functionality of the LevelManager inside SimulationRunner. I decided to move it into its own class so that we can create other types of level managers down the road. It's also fairly isolated from the rest of the SimulationRunner's functionality so it made sense to do it. But it's definitely meant to be owned by an instance of a SimulationRunner and should not outlive that instance. I like the idea of making it a private internal class, but I'd vote for punting if we're going to change the roles of the classes as @chapulina mentioned.

content.raw: Could you clarify this comment? I think that we're supporting several performers per runner, right?
content.html: Could you clarify this comment? I think that we're supporting several performers per runner, right?

content.raw:
Yes, multiple performers can be in the same level. "performer-centered" in this comment means that simulation runners are bound to one or more performers according to the configuration in the SDF file and that the performers almost never leave the simulation runner (the exception being interacting performers between multiple runners). They can however move in and out of levels. In terms of distributed sim, we still haven't addressed how a performers gets assigned to a specific simulation runner. 
It says on the design doc:
> The total number of runners will be predefined through SDF, as well as the affinity of levels and performers to each runner. 

We should probably create a task for setting the affinity of levels and performers.
content.html:
Yes, multiple performers can be in the same level. "performer-centered" in this comment means that simulation runners are bound to one or more performers according to the configuration in the SDF file and that the performers almost never leave the simulation runner (the exception being interacting performers between multiple runners). They can however move in and out of levels. In terms of distributed sim, we still haven't addressed how a performers gets assigned to a specific simulation runner. It says on the design doc:

The total number of runners will be predefined through SDF, as well as the affinity of levels and performers to each runner.

We should probably create a task for setting the affinity of levels and performers.

content.html: Thanks for the clarification! It does feel like performers being assigned simulation runners will need to be done before @carromj's A-3 demo task, not sure if he's already on it.

content.raw: Added on pull request #154
content.html: Added on pull request #154

content.raw:
There are a few assumptions here about entities that are part of a level:

* They're not moved (i.e. they retain their initial pose as described in the SDF)
* They're not modified in any other way (i.e. no systems added new components to them or modified other components)
* They're not removed during simulation
* All entities created during simulation are part of the default level

I think it's ok to have these assumptions, I'll just go ahead and document this somewhere though.
content.html:
There are a few assumptions here about entities that are part of a level:

  • They're not moved (i.e. they retain their initial pose as described in the SDF)
  • They're not modified in any other way (i.e. no systems added new components to them or modified other components)
  • They're not removed during simulation
  • All entities created during simulation are part of the default level

I think it's ok to have these assumptions, I'll just go ahead and document this somewhere though.

content.raw: Suggested some documentation on pull request #154
content.html: Suggested some documentation on pull request #154

content.raw: Yes, these are the assumptions because we use the original SDF to load models after they have been unloaded. Thanks for enumerating the assumptions and documenting them!
content.html: Yes, these are the assumptions because we use the original SDF to load models after they have been unloaded. Thanks for enumerating the assumptions and documenting them!

Thanks for adding the warning. While testing this, I realized that the code will only get here if the world has the dummy plugin though.

In fact, ign-gazebo --levels -v 4 -f ../examples/worlds/shapes.sdf doesn't load at all, unless I do this change:

diff -r eaec0df805da src/LevelManager.cc
--- a/src/LevelManager.cc       Wed Feb 06 15:22:15 2019 -0800
+++ b/src/LevelManager.cc       Wed Feb 06 15:40:34 2019 -0800
@@ -88,11 +88,14 @@
   {
     if (pluginElem == nullptr)
     {
-      ignerr << "Could not find a plugin tag with name " << kPluginName << "\n";
-      return;
+      ignerr << "Could not find a plugin tag with name " << kPluginName
+             << ". Levels will not work.\n";
     }
-    this->ReadPerformers(pluginElem);
-    this->ReadLevels(pluginElem);
+    else
+    {
+      this->ReadPerformers(pluginElem);
+      this->ReadLevels(pluginElem);
+    }
   }

   this->ConfigureDefaultLevel();
